channel.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
channel.description: Recently there has been a soldier (Sgt. Patrick Stewart) who died in Iraq. He and his wike practiced the pagan religion, Wicca. The symbol of this religion is the pentacle, which is a star with a circle around it. He is getting the plaque on his grave stone, but the government hasn't even approved it. I myself find this a breach in the US constitution, and George Bush is taking us closer and closer to the burning times, where witches and wizards had to lie to their friends and family and destroy their hard made alters. I don't expect anyone else on this forum to be Wiccan, but before you post your oppinion, remember, this is a dead soldier that died for his country and all he wants is a plaque on his grave.

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?

this kinda shit pisses me off but because i am pissed off i will stop typing

Read full topic

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
item.dc:creator: @Buzzy Buzzy
item.description:
@Buzzy wrote:

Mopar, there is a lot of differences in Catholisism and Christiantity. Also, in no way is Wicca satanic, Wicca teaches good nature towars others and part of the Wiccan rede states that what ever you do comes back to you threefold, and also that as long that it harms no one, go ahead an do it. Yes, according to the 1st ammendment, there is nothing wrong with ngraving your religous symbol on a grave. Also I can garuntee that this would not be an issue if it was a Christian soldier. Thanks for all the posts everyone.

Read full topic
item.source: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Got_Shine, post:15, topic:22877”][quote author=Got_Shine link=topic=34953.msg424225#msg424225 date=1163043442]
This is rediculous, how does this affect anyone but the soldier’s family? Isn’t religious freedom one of the rights America is founded upon?
[/quote]
His tombstone will no doubt be next to other people’s? Some people don’t want what they view to be satanic [or evil] representations desecrating their loved ones.
Perfectly reasonable…
And as I said before, there can’t be complete freedom… so it’s a tough one.[/quote]

His family couldn’t use the same defense? They may not want to view a symbol of a religion that contradicts their teachings.
[/quote]

Then throw him in a hole somewhere, or burn his body.

Read full topic

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

[quote=“bumblescum, post:9, topic:22877”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=34953.msg418576#msg418576 date=1162948938]

Either way, everyone knows that although there is a seperation of church and state in the USA, the country was founded by christians,[/quote]
Actually, this is a common misconception. The U.S. was established by a collection of believers, Deists, Agnostics, Catholics, Atheists & yes Christians. Some would contest that the founders were predominately Deist.[/quote]
Most of the people that came from Europe came because of religious persecution. Most were christian.

Got_Shine:

This is rediculous, how does this affect anyone but the soldier’s family? Isn’t religious freedom one of the rights America is founded upon?

His tombstone will no doubt be next to other people’s? Some people don’t want what they view to be satanic [or evil] representations desecrating their loved ones.
Perfectly reasonable…
And as I said before, there can’t be complete freedom… so it’s a tough one.

Read full topic

item.description:
@VG_Kobra wrote:

Paganism was defamed by the Church, thats why it was widely accepted as a derogatory term.

I think he should be allowed to have the symbol on his grave, I find the chances of someone becoming intensively offended by this highly minimal.

Read full topic

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

I fail to see how Bush has anything to do with this… I’m sure such things aren’t brought very close to the hands of Bush nor his cabinet. But hell, lets blame him anyways… :rolleyes:

And freedom isn’t so simple. There are still lines. If you want freedom, see anarchy.
So, naturally, it’s hard to figure out the lines.

And as far as separation of church and state, I feel the founders instated that more to keep government out of religion instead of visa versa.
I don’t think they’re so much worried about this single instance, but rather the future instances… since it could lead to more obscure engravings. So they need only limit it to what is publicly acceptable. (so no porn on ur tombstone :()
This would offend many people, but I see nothing wrong with it.

Read full topic

item.title: US Soldier Not Allowed Pentacle on Grave Stone- Oppinions?
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

My view is, let them do what they want. Who the hell cares what someone else puts on their grave? It has nothing to do with the presidency, so why is Bush such a prude. I hate conservatives… They really bother me. I bet they don’t like sex. :rolleyes:

I say he should get that plaque.

KyleGut3:

Btw, Pagan is generally a disapproving term.

That’s true. Pagan is mostly used as a derogatory term.

Read full topic

Either way, everyone knows that although there is a seperation of church and state in the USA, the country was founded by christians, and therefore most of us have christian values. He knew that when he enlisted in the army as well.
